118TH CONGRESS 
2D SESSION H. R. 10473 
To prevent covered vehicle manufacturers from accessing, selling, or otherwise 
selling certain covered vehicle data, and for other purposes. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
DECEMBER 18, 2024 
Mr. BURLISON (for himself and Mr. BIGGS) introduced the following bill; 
which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce 
A BILL 
To prevent covered vehicle manufacturers from accessing, 
selling, or otherwise selling certain covered vehicle data, 
and for other purposes. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa-
1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 
2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 
3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Auto Data Privacy 
4
and Autonomy Act’’. 
5
SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. 
6
In this Act: 
7
(1) COMMISSION.—The term ‘‘Commission’’ 
8
means the Federal Trade Commission. 
9

4
the Director of the National Institute of Standards 
5
and Technology. 
6

cle’’ has the same meaning given such term in sec-
8
tion 30102(a) of title 49, United States Code, and

includes a motor vehicle trailer.

(5) OPERATOR
DATA.—The term ‘‘operator 
11
data’’ means— 
12
(A) all electronic data generated or proc-
13
essed onboard a covered vehicle, such as data 
14
generated by sensors, receivers, computer proc-
15
essing units, or other vehicle components; and 
16
(B) data stored in a covered vehicle gen-
17
erated by the user of such covered vehicle. 
18

PERSONALLY
IDENTIFIABLE
INFORMA-

TION.—The term ‘‘personally identifiable informa-

tion’’ means information that— 
21
(A) directly identifies an individual such as 
22
the name, address, social security number or 
23
other identifying number or code, telephone 
24
number, or email address of an individual;

vidual; or

activity of an individual. 
5
(7) SECRETARY.—The term ‘‘Secretary’’ means 
6
the Secretary of Transportation. 
7
(8) SECURE.—The term ‘‘secure’’ means, with 
8
respect to the interface for access and control of op-
9
erator data described in section 4(c), designed to 
10
prevent malicious or unauthorized use or access of 
11
such data.

nology-neutral’’ means, with respect to the interface

dice towards any technology or service used to access

prietary technologies by a covered vehicle owner or

manufacturer.

PREFERENCE.—The term ‘‘user

preference’’ means any choice with respect to a 
23
configurable setting of a covered vehicle made by or

SEC. 3. OPERATOR DATA PRIVACY AND SECURITY. 
3
(a) PROHIBITION ON MANUFACTURERS.—A manu-
4
facturer of a covered vehicle may not, with respect to the 
5
covered vehicle of a covered vehicle owner that is manufac-
6
tured by such manufacturer— 
7
(1) access operator data, unless— 
8
(A) the covered vehicle owner affirmatively 
9
consents to such manufacturer accessing such 
10
data and such consent— 
11
(i) is freely given; 
12
(ii) is informed, specific, and unam-
13
biguous; 
14
(iii) is in writing; and 
15
(iv) may be easily withdrawn; or 
16
(B) such data is accessed solely to improve 
17
covered vehicle performance or safety; 
18
(2) sell, lease, or otherwise share operator data, 
19
unless— 
20
(A) required to do so— 
21
(i) pursuant to a lawfully executed 
22
warrant; 
23
(ii) pursuant to a court order that 
24
provides the covered vehicle owner notice 
25

5
covered vehicle owner or, in the event of the 
6
death or incapacity of such person, the next of 
7
kin of such owner; or 
8

States citizen or lawful permanent resident to the

Korea.

SEC. 4. OPERATOR DATA ACCESS. 
3
(a) IN GENERAL.—A manufacturer of a covered vehi-
4
cle shall provide to a covered vehicle owner access to, and 
5
control of, operator data— 
6
(1) at no cost beyond the purchase price of 
7
such vehicle; 
8
(2) without any restriction or limitation, con-
9
sistent with subsection (c); and 
10
(3) without a requirement that the covered ve-
11
hicle owner—

(A) pay a fee or purchase a license to 
13
decrypt operator data; or 
14
(B) use a device provided by such manu-
15
facturer to access and use operator data.

17

19
enable the operation of open application programming

interfaces that—

(1) facilitate deletion of all data stored in a cov-
22
ered vehicle generated by the user of such covered 
23
vehicle; and

(a) STANDARDS REPORT.—Not later than 180 days

hicle owners, and with other agencies as necessary, estab-

lish 1 or more standards for the technology-neutral, stand-

ards-based, secure interface required by section 4(c).

(a) UNFAIR OR DECEPTIVE ACT OR PRACTICE.—A 
8

(15 U.S.C. 57a(a)(1)(B)).

of the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C. 41 
18
et seq.) were incorporated into and made a part of 
19
this Act. 
20
(2) PRIVILEGES AND IMMUNITIES.—Any person 
21
who violates this Act shall be subject to the penalties 
22
and entitled to the privileges and immunities pro-
23
vided in the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 
24
U.S.C. 41 et seq.).

SEC. 7. RELATION TO OTHER LAWS. 
4
This Act supersedes any statute, rule, requirement, 
5
or other legal obligation of a State or political subdivision 
6
thereof, or any Federal law or regulation, that relates to 
7
the requirements in this Act. 
8
SEC. 8. DISCLOSURE OF CONFIDENTIAL BUSINESS INFOR-
9
MATION. 
10
Except as provided in section 4, nothing in this Act 
11
shall require a manufacturer of a covered vehicle to di-
12
vulge confidential business information (as that term is 
13
defined in section 512.3(c) of title 49, Code of Federal 
14
Regulations). 
15
SEC. 9. EFFECTIVE DATE. 
16
This Act shall take effect on the date that is 3 
17
months after the date of enactment of this Act. 
18
SEC. 10. NO NEW APPROPRIATIONS. 
19
The Commission shall carry out this Act using unob-
20
ligated funds appropriated to the Commission and avail-
21
able as of the date of the enactment of this Act.

SEC. 114. PRIVACY-ENHANCING TECHNOLOGY PILOT PRO-
5
GRAM. 
6
(a) PRIVACY-ENHANCING TECHNOLOGY DEFINED.— 
7
In this section, the term ‘‘privacy-enhancing tech-
8
nology’’— 
9
(1) means any software or hardware solution, 
10
cryptographic algorithm, or other technical process 
11
of extracting the value of information without sub-
12
stantially reducing the privacy and security of the 
13
information; and 
14
(2) includes technologies with functionality 
15
similar to homomorphic encryption, differential pri-
16
vacy, zero-knowledge proofs, synthetic data genera-
17
tion, federated learning, and secure multi-party com-
18
putation. 
19
(b) ESTABLISHMENT.—Not later than 1 year after 
20
the date of the enactment of this Act, the Commission 
21
shall establish and carry out a pilot program to encourage 
22
private sector use of privacy-enhancing technologies for 
23
the purposes of protecting covered data to comply with 
24
section 109. 
25

Æ 
Public Law 118–104 
118th Congress 
An Act 
To provide the Congressional Budget Office with necessary authorities to expedite 
the sharing of data from executive branch agencies, and for other purposes. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representatives of 
the United States of America in Congress assembled, 
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Congressional Budget Office 
Data Access Act’’. 
SEC. 
2. 
CONDITIONS 
OF 
DISCLOSURE 
FOR 
FEDERAL 
AGENCY 
INFORMATION WITH THE CONGRESSIONAL BUDGET OFFICE. 
Subsection (b) of section 552a of title 5, United States Code 
(commonly known as the ‘‘Privacy Act of 1974’’), is amended— 
(1) by redesignating paragraphs (11) and (12) as paragraphs 
(12) and (13), respectively; and 
(2) by inserting after paragraph (10) the following: 
‘‘(11) to the Director of the Congressional Budget Office, 
or any authorized representative of the Director, in the course 
of performance of the duties of the Congressional Budget 
Office;’’. 
Approved October 2, 2024. 
5 USC 101 note. 
Congressional 
Budget Office 
Data Access Act.
